title: About to complete chp 13 BK, question about car's certificate of title.
question: My cuz is about to complete his chp13 BK. Under trustee financials, looks like the car payments for his car has been completed. But there are some other payments still in progress and expected to complete in couple of months. Can he go ahead and ask the car creditor to send him the certificate of title since his car officially got paid off even if his chp13 case is yet to be complete(but close in completing)? Or he does not have option but to wait until chp13 is officially complete and all other debts discharged? Please advise CA attorneys since my cuz is having a run around from his lawyer since perhaps his case is almost complete.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy proof of claim,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Used cars
answers:
This is a classic "it depends" question. It depends upon what the plan was to pay. Did it pay 100% of the claim at the original interest rate with fees etc? If so, the creditor is probably in the process of completing the paperwork to return the pink to you cuz. If the plan altered any of the terms of the original financing, the creditor will wait until the plan is completed and discharge entered, as they still have potential rights (unpaid principal, interest and/or fees) if the case is dismissed for some reason.
Without knowing the terms of the plan and the amount of the claim etc. we can't know for certain. His lawyer needs to sit down with him and advise him.

It is not certain that the holder of the title will send it to your cousin unless you request it. What very commonly happens is that a chapter 13 is pending for many years, and the creditor may not be fully aware that the payoff has been completed, and is not communicating with the debtor to avoid automatic stay problems.

You best bet is to call them up and ask for it - worst they can do is say no. But after the BK discharge is entered and the case closed, you will need to contact them again and insist they turn it over. If not, or if they give you the run around, the solution is a motion in the chapter 13 case to compel them to hand it over. That will probably resolve it.

Not a California attorney, but the Bankruptcy Code provides that the lien survives until, "the holder of such claim retain the lien securing such claim until the earlier of—(aa) the payment of the underlying debt determined under nonbankruptcy law; or(bb) discharge under section 1328". 11 U.S.C. § 1325(a)(5)(B)(i)(I).

Most of the time, plans provide for payment of a lower interest rate than the contract provided, and some of the time, the plan only provides for payment of the value which is less than the payoff balance at the time of filing of the case. Even when the plan calls for payment of the contract rate owed to the auto lender, the trustee normally does not pay interest between the petition date and the confirmation date.

Thus, it is likely that even though the trustee's record shows claim secured by the vehicle has been paid in full, the claim has not been paid in full per the creditor's records. If the creditor has not been paid its full claim plus interest at its contract rate under the terms of the promissory note or contract, then your cousin will not receive his title until after the discharge is granted.

If the creditor rec'd payment equal to the amount of the claim it filed, plus interest, plus any amounts added for insurance, they have been paid in full. Whether or not they will try to hold title to the car as ransom to collect extra amounts is anybody's guess. If it is a major bank/lender, they will probably deliver the title upon payment of the amount they claimed in their Proof of Claim. If they are a used car lot, or some borderline legitimate finance company, who knows? If he gets any static from the lender, contact the trustee (or the lawyer who filed the case) and see what they can do to help. Good luck.
the creditor for a vehicle will usually send the title if the loan has been paid in full. Your cousin can call the creditor and ask for the title. there is no harm in trying
